29.verse: Saul dreaded him all the more, and Saul was David’s enemy for the rest of his life.

30.verse: The Philistine leaders continued to go out to battle, and whenever they went out, David would encounter them with more success than all of Saul’s other servants, so that his name became well known.

1.verse: Chapter 19 -Jonathan Defends David. -Saul told his son Jonathan and all his servants that they should kill David, but Jonathan, Saul’s son, was very fond of David.

2.verse: Jonathan informed David about it saying, “Saul, my father, is seeking to kill you. Be on your guard tomorrow morning. Stay in some secret place and hide there.

3.verse: I will go out and stand beside my father in the field where you are. I will speak to him about you, and I will tell you what I discover.”

4.verse: Jonathan spoke well of David to his father Saul. He said to him, “May the king not wrong his servant David, for he has not wronged you. What he has done has only been to your benefit.

5.verse: He risked his life when he killed the Philistine. The Lord won a great victory for all of Israel. You saw it and you rejoiced. Why would you sin against innocent blood by killing David for no reason?”

6.verse: Saul listened to Jonathan, and Saul swore, “As the Lord lives, he will not be killed.”

7.verse: Jonathan then called David, and Jonathan informed him about all these things. Jonathan brought David to Saul, and he was in his presence as he had been before.

8.verse: War broke out again, and David went out to fight against the Philistines. He struck them down, slaughtering many, and they fled from him.

9.verse: David Is Saved by Michal. -Now an evil spirit from the Lord was upon Saul, and he was sitting in his house, holding a javelin in his hand while David was playing some music.

10.verse: Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the javelin, but he eluded Saul, and he drove the javelin into the wall. That night David fled and escaped.

11.verse: Saul sent deputies to David’s house to watch for him and to kill him in the morning. Michal, David’s wife, told him, “If you do not save yourself tonight, you will be killed tomorrow.”

12.verse: So Michal lowered David down through a window, and he fled and escaped.

13.verse: Michal took a teraphim and laid it on the bed, and she placed a goat’s hair pillow where his head would be, and she covered it over with clothes.

14.verse: When Saul sent deputies to seize David, she said, “He is sick.”

15.verse: Saul sent the deputies back to look for David saying, “Bring him back to me on a litter so I can kill him.”

16.verse: When the deputies arrived, they found the teraphim in the bed with the pillow of goat’s hair where the head would be.

17.verse: Saul said to Michal, “Why have you deceived me by sending away my enemy so that he could escape?” Michal said to Saul, “He said to me, ‘Let me go or I will kill you.’ ”

18.verse: David, Samuel, and Saul in Ramah. -When David had fled and made his escape, he went to Samuel in Ramah and told him everything that Saul had done to him. He and Samuel went to Naioth and they stayed there.

19.verse: Saul heard that David was in Naioth in Ramah.

20.verse: He sent deputies to capture David. They saw a band of prophets there prophesying, and Samuel was their leader. The Spirit of God rushed upon Saul’s deputies, and they prophesied as well.

21.verse: Saul was told about it, and he sent other deputies, but they prophesied as well. A third time Saul sent deputies, but they also prophesied.

22.verse: Saul and the Prophets. -Finally, he himself went to Ramah, and he came to the great well in Secu. He asked, “Where are Samuel and David?” Someone told him, “They are at Naioth in Ramah.”

23.verse: So he went to Naioth in Ramah, and the Spirit of God rushed upon him, too. He walked along, prophesying, until he arrived at Naioth.

24.verse: He stripped off his clothes and he prophesied as he had in Samuel’s presence. He laid down naked all that day and all that night. This is why they say, “Is Saul also one of the prophets?”

1.verse: Chapter 20 -David and Jonathan’s Friendship. -David fled from Naioth in Ramah and he went to Jonathan and said, “What have I done? What is my crime? How have I wronged your father that he is trying to take my life?”

2.verse: He answered him, “You will surely not die! Everything that my father does, whether it is important or insignificant, he confides to me. Why would my father hide this from me? It is just not so.”

3.verse: But David swore an oath saying, “Your father knows very well that you like me, so he said to himself, ‘I will not let Jonathan know about it, lest he be grieved by it.’ As the Lord lives and as you live, there is only one step between me and death.”

4.verse: So Jonathan said to David, “Whatever you want me to do for you, I will do it.”

5.verse: David said to Jonathan, “Tomorrow is the new moon celebration, and I am supposed to dine with the king. Let me go and hide myself in the field until the evening of the day after tomorrow.

6.verse: If your father should miss me, tell him, ‘David begged me for permission to hurry to Bethlehem because they are offering an annual sacrifice there for the whole clan.’

7.verse: If he says, ‘That is fine,’ then your servant is safe. But if he becomes very angry, you can be sure that he is plotting harm.

8.verse: Deal kindly with your servant, for you have entered into a covenant before the Lord with your servant. If I am guilty, kill me yourself, why should you hand me over to your father?”

9.verse: Jonathan answered, “Never! If I knew for sure that my father was planning to harm you, would I not tell you?”

10.verse: David asked Jonathan, “Who will tell me if your father’s answer is harsh?”

11.verse: Jonathan said, “Come. Let us go out into the field.” So they went out into the field together.

12.verse: Jonathan said to David, “By the Lord, the God of Israel, by this time on the day after tomorrow, I will have sounded out my father. If he is well disposed toward David, will I not send word to you to let you know?

13.verse: Otherwise, may the Lord do this and more to Jonathan. But if my father wishes to harm you, I will send you away so that you can be safe. May the Lord be with you as he has been with my father.

14.verse: Only will you not treat me with the Lord’s kindness as long as I live, so that I not be killed?

15.verse: Never cease being kind to my family, even when the Lord has eliminated all of David’s enemies from the face of the earth.”

16.verse: So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David saying, “May the Lord take vengeance on all of David’s enemies.”

17.verse: Jonathan made David swear again by his love for him, for he loved him more than he loved himself.

18.verse: Then Jonathan said to him, “Tomorrow is a new moon, and you will be missed because your seat will be empty.

19.verse: The day after tomorrow, hurry down to the place where you hid yourself when this trouble began, and stay by the stone of Ezel.

20.verse: I will shoot three arrows off to the side of it, as if I were shooting at a target.

21.verse: Then I will send a boy out saying, ‘Go and find the arrows.’ If I say to him, ‘Look, the arrows are on this side of you. Bring them,’ then, as the Lord lives, you are safe, there is no danger.

22.verse: But if I say to the boy, ‘Look, the arrows are ahead of you,’ then go on your way, for the Lord is sending you.

23.verse: The Lord is a witness between me and you forever in regard to the things about which we have spoken.”

24.verse: David’s Absence. -So David hid himself in the field. When the new moon celebration began and the king sat down to eat,

25.verse: the king sat in his usual place by the wall. Jonathan sat facing him, and Abner was sitting by Saul’s side, but David’s place was empty.

26.verse: Saul did not say anything that day, because he thought, “Something must have happened to him so that he is impure, surely he is unclean.”

27.verse: But the next day, the second day of the month, David’s place was still empty. Saul asked Jonathan, his son, “Why did the son of Jesse not come to eat yesterday nor today?”

28.verse: Jonathan answered Saul, “David begged me for permission to go to Bethlehem.

29.verse: He said to me, ‘Please let me go, for our family is offering a sacrifice in the city. My brother has told me to be there. If I have found favor with you, please, let me leave to go to see my brothers.’This is why he has not come to the king’s table.”

30.verse: Saul became angry at Jonathan and he said to him, “You son of a perverse and rebellious woman. I knew that you sided with the son of Jesse to your own shame and the shame of your mother’s nakedness.

31.verse: For as long as the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be stable. Send for him and bring him to me, for he must die.”

32.verse: Jonathan answered Saul, his father, saying, “Why must he die? What has he done?”

33.verse: Saul cast a javelin at him to kill him. Jonathan thus knew that his father intended to kill David.

34.verse: Jonathan was enraged and he got up from table. He did not eat on the second day of the month because he was angry at his father for the shameful way he had treated David.

35.verse: Jonathan Warns David. -The next morning, Jonathan went out into the field at the time he had arranged with David. He had a small boy with him.

36.verse: He said to the boy, “Run, find the arrows that I shoot.” The boy ran off, and he shot an arrow beyond him.

37.verse: When the boy arrived at the place that Jonathan had shot the arrow, Jonathan said, “Is the arrow not ahead of you?”

38.verse: Then Jonathan cried out to the boy, “Hurry, run, do not stop!” The boy picked up Jonathan’s arrows and returned to his master.

39.verse: (The boy did not know anything about this, only Jonathan and David knew what was happening.)

40.verse: Jonathan gave his weapons to his boy and said, “Go, carry them into the city.”

41.verse: After the boy had left, David got up from the south side of the place, and he bowed down three times before him, face to the ground. They kissed one another, and they wept over one another, David more so.

42.verse: Jonathan said to David, “Go in peace, since we have both sworn in the name of the Lord saying, ‘May the Lord be between me and you, between my descendants and your descendants, forever.’ ” He got up and left, and Jonathan went back into the city.

1.verse: Chapter 21 -The Priest and the Holy Band. -David came to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech was afraid when he encountered David and he said to him, “Why are you alone? Why is no one with you?”

2.verse: David said to Ahimelech the priest, “The king sent me on some business, and he said to me, ‘Do not let anyone know anything about this task on which I am sending you or what I commanded you to do.’ I have sent my young men to such and such a place.

3.verse: Now, therefore, what do you have at hand? Give me five loaves of bread or whatever can be found.”

4.verse: The priest answered David saying, “I do not have any regular bread at hand, but there is consecrated bread, if the young men have abstained from being with women.”

5.verse: David answered the priest saying, “We have assuredly abstained from being with women these three days since I set out. The young men’s gear is consecrated even on missions that are not consecrated. How much more is their gear consecrated today.”

6.verse: So the priest gave him the consecrated bread, because there was no other bread than the shewbread. The shewbread had been removed from before the Lord and taken away when it was replaced by the hot bread.

7.verse: One of Saul’s servants was there that day, detained before the Lord. His name was Doeg, the Edomite, and he was Saul’s chief shepherd.

8.verse: Goliath’s Sword. -David asked Ahimelech, “Do you have a spear or a sword at hand? I did not bring either my sword nor any other weapon because the king’s mission had to be done in haste.”

9.verse: The priest answered, “The sword of Goliath, the Philistine whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want it, take it, because it is the only one here.” David said, “There is none like it, give it to me.”

10.verse: That day David rose up and fled because he was afraid of Saul. He went to Achish, the king of Gath.

11.verse: The servants of Achish said to him, “Is this not David, the king of the land? Is he not the one they sing about as they dance, ‘Saul has killed his thousands, David has killed his ten thousands.’ ”

12.verse: David Pretends Insanity. -David took these words to heart, and he was terrified of Achish, the king of Gath.

13.verse: He pretended to be out of his mind in front of them. While he was on his hands he would pound on the doors to the gate, and he would drool down his beard.

14.verse: Achish said to his servants, “Look at the man! He is out of his mind! Why did you bring him to me?

15.verse: Am I so in need of people who are out of their mind that you brought me this man who is acting so strange? Must this man come into my house?”

1.verse: Chapter 22 -David Flees. -David left and escaped to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all of his father’s household heard, they went down to him there.

2.verse: Everyone who was in distress, everyone who was in debt, and everyone who was discontented gathered around him, and he became their leader. He had about four hundred men with him.

3.verse: From there, David traveled to Mizpah in Moab. He said to the king of Moab, “Please let my father and my mother stay with you until I know what God will do with me.”

4.verse: He brought them to the king of Moab, and they lived with him the whole time that David was in the stronghold.

5.verse: But the prophet Gad said to David, “Do not stay in the stronghold. Leave, and go to the land of Judah.” David left and went into the forest of Hareth.

6.verse: Doeg Betrays Ahimelech. -Saul heard that David and his men had been discovered. Saul, holding a spear in his hand, was sitting in Gibeah under the tree of Ramah, and all of his servants were standing around him.

7.verse: Saul said to his servants who were standing around him, “Hear now, you Benjaminites. Will each of you give fields and vineyards to the son of Jesse? Will you all be officers of thousands and officers of hundreds?

8.verse: Is that why all of you have conspired against me? No one tells me when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse. None of you is concerned about me or tells me that my son has incited my servant to lie in wait for me today.”

9.verse: But Doeg the Edomite, who was standing with Saul’s servants, said, “I saw the son of Jesse go to Nob, to Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub.

10.verse: Ahimelech inquired of the Lord for him, and he gave him provisions, and he gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.”

11.verse: Saul Slays the Priests. -The king summoned Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, the priest, as well as all of his father’s family in Nob who were also priests. All of them came to the king.

12.verse: He said, “Listen now, O son of Ahitub.” He answered, “Here I am, my lord.”

13.verse: Saul said to him, “Why have you conspired with the son of Jesse against me? You gave him bread and a sword. You inquired of God whether he should lie in wait for me today.”

14.verse: Ahimelech answered the king, “Who among all of your servants is as faithful as David, the king’s son-in-law, who goes about at your bidding, and who is respected in your house?

15.verse: Was that the first time I inquired of the Lord for him? No! Let the king not accuse your servant or any of my father’s family, for your servant knows absolutely nothing about any of this.”

16.verse: The king said, “You must die, Ahimelech, you and all of your father’s family.”

17.verse: The king said to the guards who were standing around him, “Turn around and kill the priests of the Lord, for they are in league with David. They knew about his fleeing, and they did not tell me.” But the king’s servants would not stretch out their hands to fall upon the priests of the Lord.

18.verse: So the king said to Doeg, “You turn around and fall upon the priests.” Doeg the Edomite turned around, and he fell upon the priests, killing eighty-five men who wore a linen ephod that day.

19.verse: He put Nob, the city of the priests, to the sword: men, women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep.

20.verse: Abiathar Escapes. -Now one of the sons of Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub, escaped. He was named Abiathar, and he fled to David.

21.verse: Abiathar told David that Saul had killed the Lord’s priests.

22.verse: David said to Abiathar, “I knew that day, when I saw that Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would surely tell Saul. I have caused the death of everyone in your father’s family.

23.verse: Stay with me, and do not be afraid. The same man who seeks my life seeks your life as well, but you will be safe with me.”

1.verse: Chapter 23 -David Rescues Keilah. -Some people then spoke to David saying, “Look, the Philistines are attacking Keilah and they are robbing the threshing floors.”

2.verse: David inquired of the Lord saying, “Shall I go to attack these Philistines?” The Lord said to David, “Go attack the Philistines and rescue Keilah.”

3.verse: David’s men said to him, “Look, we are afraid here in Judah. How much more would we be if we went to Keilah to fight against the armies of the Philistines?”

4.verse: David inquired of the Lord once again, and the Lord said, “Rise, go down to Keilah, for I will deliver the Philistines into your hands.”

5.verse: David and his men went to Keilah and they fought with the Philistines. They slaughtered many of them, and they brought away their livestock. Thus David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.

6.verse: When Abiathar, the son of Ahimelech, fled to David at Keilah, he went down with an ephod in his hand.

7.verse: Saul Chases David. -Saul was told that David had gone to Keilah. Saul said, “God has delivered him into my hands for he has trapped himself behind gates and bars.”

8.verse: Then Saul assembled all of the people for war, to go down to Keilah and lay siege to David and his men.

9.verse: David knew that Saul was plotting evil against him, so he said to Abiathar the priest, “Bring the ephod here.”

10.verse: David said, “O Lord, the God of Israel, your servant has truly heard that Saul is seeking to come to Keilah to destroy the city on account of me.

11.verse: Will the men of Keilah deliver me into his hands? Will Saul come down here as your servant has heard? O Lord, the God of Israel, I beg you to tell your servant.” The Lord said, “He will come down.”

12.verse: Then David said, “Will the men of Keilah deliver me and my men into the hands of Saul?” The Lord answered, “They will deliver you over.”

13.verse: So David and his men (there were around six hundred of them) left Keilah and went wherever they could go. Saul heard that David had left Keilah, so he halted the pursuit.

14.verse: David stayed in the wilderness strongholds, and he remained in the hill country of the Desert of Ziph. Saul sought him every single day, but God did not deliver him into his hands.

15.verse: David realized that Saul was coming out to seek his life while he was in the Desert of Ziph at Horesh.

16.verse: Jonathan, Saul’s son, arose and went to David in Horesh and encouraged him in God.

17.verse: This is what he said to him, “Do not be afraid, for the hand of Saul, my father, is not going to find you. You will be the king over Israel, and I will be next to you. Even my father Saul knows that.”

18.verse: The two of them made a covenant before the Lord. David stayed in the woods, and Jonathan returned home.

19.verse: The Ziphites then came up to Saul in Gibeah saying, “Is David not hiding with us in strongholds in the woods, on the hill of Hachilah which is to the south of Jeshimon?

20.verse: Therefore, come down as you wish to, O king, come down, and for our part we will deliver him into the king’s hands.”

21.verse: Saul said, “May you be blessed by the Lord, for you have had compassion on me.

22.verse: Go, please, and prepare yourselves. Investigate and reconnoiter where he is hidden and find out who has seen him there, for I have been told that he is very clever.

23.verse: See, therefore, and find out about all the places where he is hiding, then come back to me with certain information. Then I will go with you, and if he is in the land, I will search for him all throughout the thousands of Judah.”

24.verse: Escape from Saul. -They rose up and preceded Saul to Ziph. David and his men were in the Desert of Maon, in the Arabah to the south of Jeshimon.

25.verse: Saul and his men were searching, and when David was told about it, he went down to the rock and stayed in the Desert of Maon. Saul heard about this and pursued David in the Desert of Maon.

26.verse: Saul was on one side of the mountain, and David and his men were on the other side of the mountain. David, out of fear, hurried to get away. Saul and his men were trying to surround David and his men to capture them.

27.verse: A messenger came to Saul saying, “Come quickly, for the Philistines have invaded the land.”

28.verse: Saul broke off his pursuit of David and he left to fight against the Philistines. This is why they called that place the Rock of Escape.

1.verse: Chapter 24 -David Spares Saul’s Life. -David went up from there and dwelt in the strongholds of En-gedi.

2.verse: When Saul returned from pursuing after the Philistines, he was told, “David is in the desert in En-gedi.”

3.verse: Saul took three thousand chosen men from out of all of Israel, and he went out and sought David and his men on the rocks of the wild goats.

4.verse: He came to the sheepfolds along the way, and there was a cave there. Saul entered it to relieve himself, and David and his men stayed in the recesses of the cave.

5.verse: David’s men said to him, “This is the day that the Lord spoke of when he said, ‘I will deliver your enemy into your hands, you may do to him as you see fit.’ ” David got up and secretly cut off a corner of Saul’s robe.

6.verse: But David’s conscience began to bother him because he had cut off a corner of Saul’s robe.

7.verse: He said to his men, “The Lord forbid that I should do such a thing to my lord, lifting my hand against the Lord’s anointed, for he is the Lord’s anointed.”

8.verse: With these words David rebuked his servants, and he would not let them rise up against Saul.Saul rose from the cave and went on his way.

9.verse: David also arose and left the cave. He cried out after Saul saying, “My lord, the king.” Saul looked back and saw David bowed down, face to the ground, lying prostrate.

10.verse: David said to Saul, “Why do you listen to men who say, ‘David is trying to harm you?’

11.verse: Behold, you have seen for yourself today how the Lord delivered you into my hands in the cave. Some urged me to kill you, but I spared you. I said, ‘I will not raise up my hand against my lord, for he is an anointed one of the Lord.’

12.verse: Look, my father, see the corner of your robe in my hand. I cut off the corner of your robe, but I did not kill you. So see and understand that I am not guilty of wrongdoing or rebellion. I have not wronged you, but yet you hunt me to take my life.

13.verse: May the Lord be the judge between me and you. May the Lord take my vengeance upon you, but I will not raise my hand against you.

14.verse: As the old proverb states, ‘Evil deeds come from evil doers,’ but I will not raise my hand against you.

15.verse: Against whom has the king of Israel come out? Whom do you pursue? After a dead dog? After a flea?

16.verse: May the Lord be a judge and decide between me and you. May he examine my cause and plead it; may he deliver me out of your hands.”

17.verse: Saul’s Apology to David. -When David had finished saying these things to Saul, Saul said, “Is that your voice, my son, David?” And Saul cried out and wept.

18.verse: He said to David, “You are more righteous than I am, for you have treated me well, but I have treated you poorly.

19.verse: Today you have revealed to me how you have treated me well, for the Lord had delivered me into your hands, but you did not kill me.

20.verse: When a man finds his enemy, does he allow him to walk away unharmed? May the Lord richly reward you for what you have done to me today.

21.verse: Truly, now I know that the kingdom of Israel will be firmly placed in your hands.

22.verse: Now swear to me by the Lord that you will not cut off my descendants after me, nor will you eliminate my name from my father’s family.”

1.verse: Chapter 25 -Death of Samuel. -Now Samuel died, and all of Israel gathered to mourn for him. They buried him at his home in Ramah. David then went down into the Desert of Paran.

2.verse: Nabal and Abigail. -There was a certain man from Maon who had property in Carmel, for he was very wealthy. He owned three thousand sheep and one thousand goats, and he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.

3.verse: His name was Nabal, and his wife’s name was Abigail. She was a good woman, intelligent and beautiful, but her husband, who was a Calebite, was difficult and disagreeable in his dealings.

4.verse: While David was in the wilderness, he heard that Nabal was shearing his sheep.

5.verse: David sent ten young men, and David said to the young men, “Go up to Carmel and approach Nabal, greeting him in my name.

6.verse: Say to him, ‘May you have a long and pleasant life, and may your household prosper, and may all that you own multiply.

7.verse: I have heard that you were shearing. When your shepherds were with us, we did not harm them nor did anything that belonged to them go missing the whole time they were at Carmel.

8.verse: Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore, show your favor to these young men, for we are here on a feast day. Please give your servants and your son David whatever comes to hand.’ ”

9.verse: When David’s young men arrived, they said all of these things to Nabal in David’s name. Then they waited.

10.verse: Nabal answered David’s servants, “Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? There are many slaves these days who have run away from their masters.

11.verse: Why should I take my bread and my water, and the meat that I have butchered for my shearers, and give them to men when I do not even know from where they have come?”

12.verse: David’s young men turned and went on their way. They came back and told him all these things.

13.verse: David said to his men, “Let each man put on his sword.” Each man put on his sword, and David also put on his sword. About four hundred men went up with David while the other two hundred remained with the supplies.

14.verse: One of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, “Behold, David sent messengers into the wilderness to greet our master, and he insulted them.

15.verse: But they have treated us well, and they have not harmed us, nor did anything go missing when we were wandering about in the fields near them.

16.verse: Night and day, the whole time that we were with them tending the sheep, they were like a wall around us.

17.verse: Now think about it and figure out what you will do, for certain disaster is awaiting our master and his entire household. He is a son of Belial, and no one can speak to him.”

18.verse: Abigail acted quickly. She took two hundred loaves of bread, two skins of wine, five butchered sheep, five seahs of parched grain, one hundred raisin cakes, and two hundred fig cakes, and she loaded it all on donkeys.

19.verse: She then said to her servants, “Go on ahead, I will follow you.” But she did not tell this to her husband.

20.verse: As she was riding along on the donkey, she went down into a mountain ravine, and there was David and his men coming down the other side, and she met them.

21.verse: David had been saying, “Surely it was in vain that I watched over all of his things in the wilderness so that nothing that he owned went missing. He has paid me back evil for good.

22.verse: May God do this to David, and even more, if by morning I have left alive even one male who belongs to him.”

23.verse: When Abigail saw David, she quickly got off the donkey, and she fell down before David, bowing her face to the ground.

24.verse: She fell at his feet and said, “Let the blame be upon me, my lord. Please permit your handmaid to speak to you, hear what your handmaid has to say to you.

25.verse: “May my lord not pay attention to this man of Belial, Nabal. He is just like his name. His name means fool, and folly is his companion. But as for me, I, your handmaid, did not see the young men whom you sent.

26.verse: “Now, my lord, as the Lord lives and you live, the Lord has kept you from coming to shed blood and avenging yourself with your own hands. May your enemies and all who seek to harm my lord be like Nabal.

27.verse: Now, may this gift that your handmaid has brought my lord be given to the young men who follow my lord.

28.verse: “I beg you, forgive your handmaid’s offense, for the Lord will surely establish an enduring dynasty for my lord because he fights the Lord’s battles. May no wrongdoing be found in you all of your days.

29.verse: Even though someone should rise up to pursue you to seek your life, my lord’s life will be bound in the bundle of life with the Lord, your God. He will launch out as from the pocket of a sling the lives of your enemies.

30.verse: “When the Lord has fulfilled all of the good things which he has said to you, my lord, and he has established you as ruler over Israel,

31.verse: then there will have no staggering burden of guilt upon my lord’s conscience for either having shed blood without cause or for my lord having sought his own revenge. When the Lord has brought my lord success, remember your handmaid.”

32.verse: David then said to Abigail, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who has sent you to meet me today.

33.verse: May you be blessed for your good advice, for today you have prevented me from coming to shed blood and seeking vengeance for myself with my own hands.

34.verse: For as surely as the Lord, the God of Israel lives, who kept me from harming you, if you had not hurried out to meet me, then by morning there would not have been even one male left to Nabal.”

35.verse: David accepted the things that she had brought him out of her hands. He said to her, “Return home in peace. See, I have listened to what you said and I have granted your request.”

36.verse: Nabal’s Death. -When Abigail returned to Nabal, he was in his house feasting as if he were at a king’s banquet. Nabal was in high spirits, for he was very drunk. She, therefore, did not tell him a thing until daybreak.

37.verse: In the morning, when Nabal was no longer under the influence of the wine, his wife told him these things. His heart failed him, and he became like a stone.

38.verse: About ten days later, the Lord struck Nabal down and he died.

39.verse: When David heard that Nabal was dead, he said, “Blessed be the Lord who has upheld my cause against Nabal for having treated me with scorn. He has kept his servant from wrongdoing, and the Lord has repaid Nabal’s wrongdoing upon his own head.”David’s Marriage to Abigail. - David sent word to Abigail, asking her to be his wife.

40.verse: David’s servants came to Abigail in Carmel and they said to her, “David has sent us to you so that he could take you as his wife.”

41.verse: She bowed down with her face to the ground, and she said, “Behold your handmaid, a servant to wash the feet of my lord’s servants.”

42.verse: Abigail quickly got up and rode on a donkey, accompanied by five of her women. She followed David’s messengers, and she became David’s wife.

43.verse: David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel, so both of them were his wives.

44.verse: But Saul gave Michal, his daughter, David’s wife, to Paltri, the son of Laish, who was from Gallim.

1.verse: Chapter 26 -David Spares Saul Again. -Now the Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah and said, “Is not David hiding himself on the hill of Hachilah, opposite Jeshimon?”

2.verse: Saul rose up and went down into the Desert of Ziph. He had three thousand of the chosen men of Israel with him, and he sought David in the Desert of Ziph.

3.verse: Saul camped by the road on the hill of Hachilah, which is opposite Jeshimon. David was staying in the desert, and he saw Saul pursuing him in the desert.

4.verse: David had sent out spies and discovered that Saul had indeed come.

5.verse: David arose and went to the place where Saul was camped. David detected the place where Saul was lying, alongside of Abner, the son of Ner, the commander of his army. Now Saul was lying within the fortifications, and the people were encamped all around him.

6.verse: David said to Ahimelech the Hittite and to Abishai, Joab’s brother, the son of Zeruiah, “Who will go down with me to Saul in the camp?” Abishai said, “I will go with you.”

7.verse: So David and Abishai went among the people by night, and they found Saul asleep within the fortifications, his spear stuck in the ground near his head. Abner and the people were lying all around him.

8.verse: Abishai said to David, “God has delivered your enemy into your hands today. Let me strike him once, pinning him to the ground. I will not have to strike him twice.”

9.verse: But David said to Abishai, “Do no violence to him. Who can stretch forth his hand against the Lord’s anointed and be guiltless?”

10.verse: David continued, “As the Lord lives, the Lord himself will strike him down. Either his time will come, or he will simply die, or he will go into battle and be killed.

11.verse: The Lord forbid that I should stretch out my hand against the Lord’s anointed. Now take the spear that is by his head and the water jar, and let us leave.”

12.verse: David took the spear that was by Saul’s head and the water jar and they left. No one had seen them, and no one knew about it, nor did anyone wake up. They all kept sleeping, for the Lord had caused them to fall into a deep sleep.

13.verse: David then crossed over to the other side, and he stood on the top of a distant hill, so that there was quite a space between them.

14.verse: David cried out to the people and to Abner, the son of Ner, “Will you not answer me Abner?” Abner said, “Who are you that you call out to the king?”

15.verse: David said to Abner, “Are you not a man? Who is like you in Israel? Why have you not kept guard over your lord, the king? Someone came in to kill the king, your lord.

16.verse: You have not done well. As the Lord lives, you deserve to die, for you have not protected your master, the Lord’s anointed. Look around now for the king’s spear and the water jar that were at his head.”

17.verse: Saul recognized David’s voice, and he said, “Is this the voice of my son David?” David answered, “It is my voice, my lord, O king.”

18.verse: He continued, “Why is my lord chasing after his servant? What have I done? What wrongdoing have I committed?

19.verse: Now may my lord, the king, listen to the words of his servant. If the Lord has incited you against me, may he now accept an offering. If it was done by humans, may they be cursed by the Lord. They have driven me out of the Lord’s inheritance, saying, ‘Go serve other gods.’

20.verse: Do not let my blood fall to the earth in the presence of the Lord. My king has come out to search for a flea, like one who goes out to hunt a partridge in the mountains.”

21.verse: Saul responded, “I have sinned. Come back, David, my son, for I will not try to harm you again because you considered my life to be precious. I have played the fool and made a terrible mistake.”

22.verse: David said, “Here is the king’s spear. Let one of your young men come over and fetch it.

23.verse: The Lord rewards each man for his righteousness and his faithfulness. The Lord delivered you into my hands today, but I would not stretch out my hand against the Lord’s anointed.

24.verse: May the Lord value my life as much as I have valued your life today. May he deliver me from all of my difficulties.”

25.verse: Saul said to David, “May you be blessed David, my son, for you will accomplish many things and you will triumph.” David went his way, and Saul returned to his home.

1.verse: Chapter 27 -David’s Flight to the Philistines. -David thought to himself, “One of these days I will perish at Saul’s hands. I might as well escape into the land of the Philistines. Saul will give up hope of catching me anywhere in the territory of Israel, and I will escape out of his hand.”

2.verse: David and his six hundred followers went over to Achish, the son of Maoch, the king of Gath.

3.verse: David stayed with Achish at Gath. Each man had his family with him, and David had his two wives: Ahinoam, the Jezreelite, and Abigail, Nabal’s wife, of Carmel.

4.verse: When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he did not go out after him anymore.

5.verse: David said to Achish, “If I have found favor in your sight, then let me be given a place in one of your country towns to live. Why should your servant live in the royal city with you?”

6.verse: That day Achish gave him Ziklag. Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah up to the present.

7.verse: David lived in the territory of the Philistines for one year and four months.

8.verse: David’s Raids. -David and his men went up and raided the Geshurites, the Gezrites, and the Amalekites. (From the days of old these were the people who lived in the land running from Shur down to the land of Egypt.)

9.verse: When David attacked a place, he did not leave a man or a woman alive. He took the sheep, oxen, donkeys, camels, and clothes, and he would then return to Achish.

10.verse: When Achish would ask, “Where have you gone raiding today,” David would say to him, “To the south of Judah, or to the south of the Jerahmeelites, or to the south of the Kenites.”

11.verse: David did not leave a man or a woman alive to bring them to Gath, for he thought they might say, “This is what David did.” He did this the whole time that he was living among the Philistines.

12.verse: Achish trusted David saying, “He has become so utterly hateful to his people, Israel, that he will be my servant forever.”

1.verse: Chapter 28 -In those days the Philistines gathered together their armies to fight against Israel. Achish said to David, “Know that you and your men are to go out to battle with me.”

2.verse: David said to Achish, “Then you will know for sure what your servant can do.” Achish said to David, “You will, therefore, be my bodyguard from now on.”

3.verse: Samuel was dead, and all of Israel had mourned for him and had buried him in Ramah, his own city. Saul had expelled mediums and wizards from out of the land.

4.verse: The Philistines assembled together and went and camped at Shunem. Saul gathered together all of Israel and they camped at Gilboa.

5.verse: When Saul saw the Philistine army, he was afraid, and his heart trembled.

6.verse: Saul inquired of the Lord, but the Lord did not answer him in dreams, or by the Urim, or through the prophets.

7.verse: Saul and the Medium. -Saul said to his servants, “Find me a woman who is a medium so that I can go to her and inquire of her.” His servants answered, “There is a woman who is a medium in Endor.”

8.verse: Saul disguised himself, putting on other clothes. He went with two men, and they came to the woman by night. He said, “Please consult a spirit for me, bring up the one whose name I give you.”

9.verse: But the woman said to him, “You surely know what Saul has done, how he has expelled mediums and wizards out of the land. Why would you set a trap for my life, bringing on my death?”

10.verse: Saul swore an oath to her by the Lord saying, “As the Lord lives, you will not be punished for this.”

11.verse: The woman asked, “Whom shall I bring up for you,” and he answered, “Bring up Samuel for me.”

12.verse: Samuel Appears. -When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out in a loud voice, and the woman said to Saul, “Why have you deceived me, Saul?”

13.verse: The king said to her, “Do not be afraid! What did you see?” She said to Saul, “I saw a spirit coming up from the earth.”

14.verse: He said to her, “What does he look like?” She said, “An old man wearing a robe came up.” Saul realized that it was Samuel, and he bowed down and prostrated his face to the ground.

15.verse: Samuel said to Saul, “Why have you bothered me by bringing me up?” Saul answered, “I am in great distress. The Philistines are fighting against me, and God has turned against me. He does not answer me anymore, either by prophets or by dreams. I have called upon you so that you can make known to me what I should do.”

16.verse: Samuel said, “Why do you question me now that the Lord has turned against you and has become your enemy?

17.verse: The Lord has done for himself exactly what he predicted through me. The Lord has ripped the kingdom out of your hand, and he has given it to your neighbor, to David.

18.verse: You did not heed the voice of the Lord nor enact his fierce rage against Amalek. Therefore, the Lord has done this thing to you today.

19.verse: The Lord will hand over both you and Israel into the hands of the Philistines. Tomorrow you and your sons will be with me. The Lord will also deliver the army of Israel into the hands of the Philistines.”

20.verse: The Medium Feeds Saul. -Saul fell full length upon the ground for he was terrified because of what Samuel had said. His strength was gone, for he had not eaten anything all day and night.

21.verse: When the woman came up to Saul and saw that he was greatly troubled, she said to him, “Look, your handmaid has obeyed your command. I have taken my life in my hands when I did what you had ordered me to do.

22.verse: Therefore, please heed the voice of your handmaid. Let me give you something to eat, and then you will have the strength to go on your way.”

23.verse: He refused and said, “I will not eat!”But both his servants and the woman kept urging him, and he finally listened to them. He got up off the ground and sat on the couch.

24.verse: The woman had a fatted calf in the house, and she quickly killed it. She took some flour, kneaded it, and baked it into loaves of unleavened bread.

25.verse: She set it before Saul and his servants. They ate, and then they got up and went on their way that night.

1.verse: Chapter 29 -The Philistines Reject David. -The Philistines gathered all of their forces together at Aphek. The Israelites camped by the spring in Jezreel.

2.verse: The lords of the Philistines were marching along with their units of hundreds and thousands while David and his men were marching at the rear with Achish.

3.verse: The lords of the Philistines said, “What about these Hebrews?” Achish replied to the lords of the Philistines, “Is this not David, a servant of Saul, the king of the Israel? He has been with me these days, these years. I have found no fault in him since he came to me up until the present.”

4.verse: The lords of the Philistines were angry with him, and the lords of the Philistines said to him, “Send that man back, let him go back to the place where you have assigned him. Do not let him go into battle with us, lest he turn against us during the battle. What other way could he reconcile to his master if not with the heads of these men?

5.verse: Is this not the David of whom they sang while they were dancing, ‘Saul has killed his thousands, and David has killed his ten thousands.’ ”

6.verse: So Achish summoned David and said, “As the Lord lives, you have been upright with me. You have done well in your going out and your coming back with your army. From the day you came to me up to the present, I have found nothing wrong in you. Nevertheless, the lords do not approve of you.

7.verse: Therefore, go back, and leave in peace, so that you not displease the lords of the Philistines.”

8.verse: David said to Achish, “But what have I done? As long as I have been with you, up until now, have you found anything in your servant that would explain why I am not able to go to fight against the enemies of my lord, the king?”

9.verse: Achish answered David, “I consider you to be as good as an angel of God. Nevertheless, the lords of the Philistines have said, ‘He will not go up with us into battle.’

10.verse: Now, therefore, rise up early in the morning with your master’s servants who have come with you. Get up at daybreak and depart.”

11.verse: David and his men arose in the morning, and they left for the land of the Philistines, and the Philistines went up to Jezreel.

1.verse: Chapter 30 -Ziklag Destroyed. -Three days later David and his men arrived in Ziklag. The Amalekites had invaded the Negeb and Ziklag; Ziklag was attacked and burned down.

2.verse: The women who were there, young and old, were taken captive. They did not kill any of them, but they carried them off and went on their way.

3.verse: When David and his men arrived in Ziklag, they found it burned to the ground and their wives and their sons and their daughters had been taken captive.

4.verse: David and his men with him wept out loud until they had no more strength to weep.

5.verse: David’s two wives, Ahinoam, the Jezreelite, and Abigail, the wife of Nabal of Carmel were also taken captive.

6.verse: David was greatly distressed because the people were talking about stoning him. Every single one of them was embittered because of his sons and his daughters, but David found strength in the Lord, his God.

7.verse: David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, “Bring the ephod out here.” Abiathar brought the ephod out to David.

8.verse: David inquired of the Lord saying, “Shall I pursue after this raiding party? Will I overtake them?” He answered him, “Pursue, for you are sure to overtake them and succeed in the rescue.”

9.verse: David Pursues the Amalekites. -David and the six hundred men who were with him left and arrived at the Wadi Besor where some stayed behind,

10.verse: for two hundred men stayed behind who were too exhausted to continue on over the Wadi Besor. David continued the pursuit with four hundred men.

11.verse: They found an Egyptian in a field and they brought him to David. They gave him bread to eat and water to drink

12.verse: as well as a piece of fig cake and two raisin cakes. When he had eaten, he revived, for he had not had anything to eat or any water to drink for three days and three nights.

13.verse: David asked him, “To whom do you belong? Where are you from?” The young man answered, “Egypt. I am a slave to an Amalekite. My master abandoned me because I became sick three days ago.

14.verse: We raided the south of the Cherethites, and the territory of Judah, and the south of Caleb, and we burned down Ziklag.”

15.verse: David said to him, “Can you lead me to this raiding party?” He answered, “Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or hand me over to my master, and I will take you down to them.”

16.verse: He took him down, and they were scattered all over the countryside, eating, drinking, and dancing to celebrate the great plunder they had taken from the land of the Philistines and the land of Judah.

17.verse: David fought them from dusk of that day until the next evening. None of them escaped except for four hundred young men who mounted their camels and fled away.

18.verse: David recovered everything that the Amalekites had carried away, and David rescued his two wives.

19.verse: Nothing was missing, not young nor old, not sons nor daughters, not plunder nor anything that they had taken. David recovered it all.

20.verse: David drove all of the flocks and herds before the livestock saying, “This is David’s plunder.”

21.verse: Division of the Spoils. -David came to the two hundred men who were so weary that they could not follow and whom David had left behind at the Wadi Besor. They came out to meet David and the people who were with him. As David and the people drew near, he greeted them.

22.verse: All of those who had gone with David but who were wicked men of Belial said, “None of them went with us, so we should not give them any of the spoil. Each of them can take his wife and children and depart.”

23.verse: David replied, “No, my brothers. You must not do that with what the Lord has given us. The Lord protected us and delivered over into our hands the raiding party that came out against us.

24.verse: Who will listen to what you are saying? The share of the man who went down into battle will be the same as the share of the man who stayed with the supplies. They will be equal shares.”

25.verse: He made this a statute and an ordinance in Israel from that day up until the present.

26.verse: When David arrived in Ziklag, he sent some of the spoils to the elders of Judah who were his friends saying, “Behold, this is a gift from the spoils of the enemies of the Lord.”

27.verse: He sent it to those who were in Bethel, to those who were in Ramoth-negeb, to those who were in Jattir,

28.verse: to those who were in Aroer, to those who were in Siphmoth, to those who were in Eshtemoa,

29.verse: to those who were in Rachal, to those who were in the cities of the Jerahmeelites, to those who were in the cities of the Kenites,

30.verse: to those who were in Hormah, to those who were in Borashan, to those who were in Athach,

31.verse: to those who were in Hebron, and to those who were in all those places where David had roamed.

1.verse: Chapter 31 -The Death of Saul. -Now the Philistines fought against Israel, and the Israelites fled before the Philistines, and many were killed at Mount Gilboa.

2.verse: The Philistines pressed hard upon Saul and his sons. His sons, Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua were killed by the Philistines.

3.verse: There was fierce fighting around Saul, and when the archers found their mark, they seriously wounded him.

4.verse: Saul said to his armor-bearer, “Draw your sword and thrust it through me, lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through and abuse me.” But the armor-bearer would not do this for he was terrified. Saul, therefore, took his sword and fell upon it.

5.verse: When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he, too, fell upon his sword and died with him.

6.verse: So Saul and his three sons and his armor-bearer and all of his men died together on the same day.

7.verse: When the Israelites on the other side of the valley and those on the other side of the Jordan saw that the Israelites had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned the cities, and the Philistines came and occupied them.

8.verse: The next day the Philistines came out to strip the dead, and they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.

9.verse: They cut off his head and stripped off his armor. They sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to proclaim the news in the temples of their idols and among the people.

10.verse: They put his armor in the temple of Astartes, and they fastened his body to the wall in Beth-shan.

11.verse: Saul Is Buried. -When those living in Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,

12.verse: all of their brave men traveled during the night and took down the bodies of Saul and his sons from the wall of Beth-shan. They went to Jabesh where they cremated them.

13.verse: They took their bones and they buried them under a tree in Jabesh, and they fasted for seven days.
